wb:indicator.wb:name: Phosphate rock, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Phosphate rock (Morocco), 70% BPL, contract, f.a.s. Casablanca
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Fertilizer Week; Fertilizer International; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Palmkernal oil, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Palmkernel Oil (Malaysia), c.I.f. Rotterdam
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ISTA Mielke GmbH, Oil World; US Department of Agriculture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Plywood, cents/sheets, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Plywood (Africa and Southeast Asia), Lauan, 3-ply, extra, 91 cm x 182 cm x 4 mm, wholesale price, spot Tokyo
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Japan Lumber Journal; International Tropical Timber Organization; Nikkei Newsletter on Commodities; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise Import Price Index, US$ (Keyfitz-Savescu)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A comprehensive merchandise import price index calculated using a simple equilibrium model that uses pooled regressions and incorporates trade of over 200 countries in 33 commodities (comprising most of the weight of the World Bank’s primary commodity coverage).The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations

wb:indicator.wb:name: Potassium Chloride, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Potassium chloride (muriate of potash), standard grade, spot, f.o.b. Vancouver
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Fertilizer Week; Fertilizer International; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Methodology
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-1 Country with operational national development strategies (rating)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Country's national development strategy is linked to medium-term expenditure framework and reflected in annual budgets. The degree to which governments take the lead in co-ordinating aid-funded activities is the subject of a specific commitment in the Paris Declaration. It is also a variable that seems to be subject to significant changes over time. Another dimension of ownership is the degree to which countries have development strategies that are clear and well operationalised, so that development efforts are effective and there is a robust basis for the alignment of aid with country policies. This is based on the World Bank's Results-Based National Development Strategies: Assessment and Challenges Ahead Report. Categorical where "A" assigned a value of 1; "B" assigned a value of 2; "C" assigned a value of 3; "D" assigned a value of 4; "E" assigned a value of 5; and "N/A" assigned a value of 6. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-10a Donor missions co-ordinated (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Encourage shared analysis on field missions work including diagnostic reviews that are joint. Donor co-ordinated missions focuses only on the proportion of (i) missions undertaken jointly by two or more donors, or (ii) missions undertaken by one donor on behalf of another (delegated co-operation). Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-10b Country-analysis co-ordinated (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Encourage shared analysis on country analytic work including diagnostic reviews that are joint. (i) Country analytic work undertaken by one or more donors jointly; (ii) Country analytic work undertaken by one donor on behalf of another donor (including work undertaken by one and/or used by another when it is co-financed and formally acknowledged in official documentation); (iii) Country analytic work undertaken with substantive involvement from government. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-11 Existence of a monitorable performance assessment framework (rating)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transparent and monitorable performance assessment frameworks to assess progress against (a) national development strategies and (b) sector programmes. Categorical where "A" assigned a value of 1; "B" assigned a value of 2; "C" assigned a value of 3; "D" assigned a value of 4; "E" assigned a value of 5; and "N/A" assigned a value of 6. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-12 Existence of a mutual accountability review (rating)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The concept of mutual accountability is an important innovation of the Paris Declaration. It develops the idea that aid is more effective when both donors and partner governments are accountable to their respective publics for the use of resources to achieve development results, and when they are also accountable to each other. The specific focus of the agreed indicator (Indicator 12) is on mutual accountability for the implementation of the Partnership Commitments included in the Declaration and any local agreements on enhancing aid effectiveness. Specifically, the country survey returns tell us whether there exists a mechanism for mutual review of progress on aid
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-2a Country financial management systems reliability (rating)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This rating is the World Bank's annual Country Policy and Institutional Assessment ratings (CPIA sub-component 13) for the quality of budgetary and financial management. This scale runs from 1 to 5 with 1 the worst and 5 the best. The focus is on the degree to which existing systems adhere to broadly accepted good practices or there is a reform programme in place to promote improved practices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-2b Country procurement systems reliability (rating)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The focus is on the degree to which existing systems adhere to broadly accepted good practices or there is a reform programme in place to promote improved practices. Reliable procurement systems are based on the common benchmarking and assessment methodology for public procurement systems developed and piloted by the Joint Venture on Procurement. Categorical where "A" assigned a value of 1; "B" assigned a value of 2; "C" assigned a value of 3; "D" assigned a value of 4; "E" assigned a value of 5; and "N/A" assigned a value of 6.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-3 Government budget estimates comprehensive and realistic (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The objective of this indicator is to improve transparency and accountability by encouraging partner countries and donors to accurately record aid as much as possible in the national budget, thereby allowing scrutiny by parliaments. Aid flows to the government sector that is reported in country's national government budgets.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-4 Technical assistance aligned and co-ordinated with country programmes (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Donor capacity-development support provided through co-ordinated programmes are consistent with country's development strategies. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-5a Aid for government sectors uses country public finanacial management systems (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Donors and aid flows that use country's public financial management systems that either (a) adhere to broadly good practices or (b) have a reform programme in place to achieve these. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-5b Aid for government sectors uses country procurement systems (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Donors and aid flows that use country's procurement systems that either (a) adhere to broadly good practices or (b) have a reform programme in place to achieve these. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-6 Project implementation units parallel to country structures (number)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Indicator 6 is a count of parallel project implementation units (PIUs), where
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-7 Aid disbursements on schedule and recorded by government (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Aid disbursements on schedule and recorded by government. The objective is two-fold. First and foremost, it is to encourage disbursements of funds within the year they are scheduled. Second, it is to encourage accurate recording of disbursements by partner authorities. Both objectives require strong cooperation between donors and partner authorities. Aid is more predictable and released according to agreed schedules in annual or multi-year frameworks. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-8 Bilateral aid that is untied (percent)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tied aid is aid provided on the condition that the recipient uses it to purchase goods and services from suppliers based in the donor country. The target for this indicator is to increase untied aid over time.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: PDI-9 Aid provided in the framework of programme-based appproaches (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Aid provided in the framework of programme-based approaches (PBAs) are a way of engaging in development co-operation based on the principles of co-ordinated support for a locally owned programme of development, such as a national development strategy, a sector programme, a thematic programme or a programme of a specific organization. Programme-based approaches share the following features: (i) Leadership by the host country or organization; (ii) A single comprehensive programme and budget framework; (iii) A formalized process for donor co-ordination and harmonization of donor procedures for reporting, budgeting, financial management and procurement; (iv) Efforts to increase the use of local systems for programme design and implementation, financial management, monitoring and evaluation. Indicators 3 to 12 (but not Indictor 8) are drawn from the Survey on Monitoring the Paris Declaration for each respective year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (www.oecd.org/dac/effectiveness/monitoring).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism: Estimate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism captures perceptions of the likelihood that the government will be destabilized or overthrown by unconstitutional or violent means, including politically-motivated violence and terrorism.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism: Number of Sources
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism captures perceptions of the likelihood that the government will be destabilized or overthrown by unconstitutional or violent means, including politically-motivated violence and terrorism.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism: Percentile Rank
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism captures perceptions of the likelihood that the government will be destabilized or overthrown by unconstitutional or violent means, including politically-motivated violence and terrorism.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism: Standard Error
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism captures perceptions of the likelihood that the government will be destabilized or overthrown by unconstitutional or violent means, including politically-motivated violence and terrorism.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactures value index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures unit value index is a weighted unit value index of exports of manufactures by industrial countries.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, IECAP

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactured exports unit value (MUV) index (% change)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures unit value index (percentage change) is calculated as the annual percentage change of a weighted unit value index of exports of manufactures by industrial countries.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, IECAP.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real effective exchange rate index (line rec, 2005 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs. This indicator corresponds to the IFS's line rec, and is based on a nominal rate adjusted for relative changes in consumer prices.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real effective exchange rate index (2010 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise Export Price Index, US$ (Keyfitz-Savescu)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: A comprehensive merchandise export price index calculated using a simple equilibrium model that uses pooled regressions and incorporates trade of over 200 countries in 33 commodities (comprising most of the weight of the World Bank’s primary commodity coverage).The base year is 2005.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations

wb:indicator.wb:name: Real Effective Exchange Rate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Real effective exchange rate is the nominal effective exchange rate (a measure of the value of a currency against a weighted average of several foreign currencies) divided by a price deflator or index of costs.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream and IMF International Finance Statistics data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rice, Thailand, 5%, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rice (Thailand), 5% broken, white rice (WR), milled, indicative price based on weekly surveys of export transactions, government standard, f.o.b. Bangkok
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: US Department of Agricuture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rice, Vietnamese, 5%, $/mt, current$
Rice, Thailand, 25%, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rice (Thailand), 25% broken, WR, milled indicative survey price, government standard, f.o.b. Bangkok
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: US Department of Agricuture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rice, Thai, A1.Special, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rice (Thailand), 100% broken, A.1 Super from 2006 onwards, government standard, f.o.b. Bangkok; prior to 2006, A1 Special, a slightly lower grade than A1 Super.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: US Department of Agricuture; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rule of Law: Estimate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rule of Law captures perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rule of Law: Number of Sources
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rule of Law captures perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rule of Law: Percentile Rank
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rule of Law captures perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rule of Law: Standard Error
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rule of Law captures perceptions of the extent to which agents have confidence in and abide by the rules of society, and in particular the quality of contract enforcement, property rights, the police, and the courts, as well as the likelihood of crime and violence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Regulatory Quality: Estimate
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Regulatory Quality captures perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Regulatory Quality: Number of Sources
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Regulatory Quality captures perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Regulatory Quality: Percentile Rank
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Regulatory Quality captures perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Regulatory Quality: Standard Error
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Regulatory Quality captures perceptions of the ability of the government to formulate and implement sound policies and regulations that permit and promote private sector development.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Worldwide Governance Indicators, The World Bank

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rubber, Singapore, cents/kg, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Rubber (Asia), RSS3 grade, Singapore Commodity Exchange Ltd (SICOM) nearby contract beginning 2004; during 2000 to 2003, Singapore RSS1; previously Malaysia RSS1
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Singapore Commodity Exchange Ltd (SICOM); Bloomberg; Rubber Association of Singapore Commodity Exchange (RASCE); International Rubber Study Group; Asian Wall Street Journal; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Rubber, TSR20, cents/kg, current$
Sawnwood, Cameroon, $/cum, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Sawnwood (Cameroon), sapele, width 6 inches or more, length 6 feet or more, f.a.s. Cameroonian ports
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Tropical Timber Organization; Marches Tropicaux et Mediterraneens; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Sawnwood, Malaysia, $/cum, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Sawnwood (Malaysia), dark red seraya/meranti, select and better quality, average 7 to 8 inches; length average 12 to 14 inches; thickness 1 to 2 inch(es); kiln dry, c. & f. UK ports, with 5% agents commission including premium for products of certified sustainable forest beginning January 2005; previously excluding the premium
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Tropical Timber Market Report; Tropical Timbers; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, youth female (% of females ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth (15-24) literacy rate (%). Female is the number of females age 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the female population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of young literate females to males (% ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gender parity index for youth literacy rate is the ratio of female youth literacy rate to male youth literacy rate. It is calculated by dividing the female value for the indicator by the male value for the indicator. A GPI equal to 1 indicates parity between females and males. In general, a value less than 1 indicates disparity in favor of males and a value greater than 1 indicates disparity in favor of females.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, youth male (% of males ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth (15-24) literacy rate (%). Male is the number of males age 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the male population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, youth total (% of people ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth (15-24) literacy rate (%). Total is the number of people age 15 to 24 years who can both read and write with understanding a short simple statement on their everyday life, divided by the population in that age group. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, adult female (% of females ages 15 and above)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adult (15+) literacy rate (%). Female is the percentage of females age 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of female literates aged 15 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, adult male (% of males ages 15 and above)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adult (15+) literacy rate (%). Male is the percentage of males age 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of male literates aged 15 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Literacy rate, adult total (% of people ages 15 and above)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adult (15+) literacy rate (%). Total is the percentage of the population age 15 and above who can, with understanding, read and write a short, simple statement on their everyday life. Generally, ‘literacy’ also encompasses ‘numeracy’, the ability to make simple arithmetic calculations. This indicator is calculated by dividing the number of literates aged 15 years and over by the corresponding age group population and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Duration of education, compulsory
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of compulsory education is the number of years that children are legally obliged to attend school.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of school attendance of orphans to school attendance of non-orphans ages 10-14
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of school attendance of orphans to school attendance of non orphans is the ratio of school attendance of orphans to school attendance of non orphans ages 10-14.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) (UN MDG site).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of female to male primary enrollment (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male primary enrollment is the percentage of girls to boys enrolled at primary level in public and private schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary education (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary education is the percentage of girls to boys enrolled at primary and secondary levels in public and private schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of girls to boys in primary and secondary education (%), path to goal
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This indicator is created for the use of DDP chart. Values are linear growth "path" to achieving the goal by 2015, given the initial value around 1990.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of female to male secondary enrollment (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male secondary enrollment is the percentage of girls to boys enrolled at secondary level in public and private schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of female to male tertiary enrollment (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male tertiary enrollment is the percentage of men to women enrolled at tertiary level in public and private schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public and private pre-primary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in public and private pre-primary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of female students. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Pre-primary is the number of female students at the pre-primary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) at the pre-primary level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in pre-primary. Public and private. All programmes. Male is the total number of male students enrolled in public and private pre-primary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pupil-teacher ratio. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Pre-primary is the number of pupils enrolled in pre-primary divided by the number of pre-primary school teachers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, preprimary (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Pre-primary. Total is the total enrollment in pre-primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of official pre-primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, preprimary, female (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Pre-primary. Female is the total female enrollment in pre-primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of official pre-primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, preprimary, male (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Pre-primary. Male is the total male enrollment in pre-primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of official pre-primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Total is the ratio of children of the official pre-primary school age who are enrolled in pre-primary school to the total population of the official pre-primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Female is the ratio of female children of the official pre-primary school age who are enrolled in pre-primary school to the female population of the official pre-primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Pre-primary. Male is the ratio of male children of the official pre-primary school age who are enrolled in pre-primary school to the male population of the official pre-primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage of private enrolment. Pre-primary.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Pre-primary is the enrolment in private pre-primary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in pre-primary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in pre-primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in pre-primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private pre-primary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in pre-primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in pre-primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private pre-primary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Percentage female teachers. Pre-primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Pre-primary is the number of female teachers at the pre-primary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the pre-primary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary school starting age (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Entrance age of primary is the age at which students would enter primary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross primary graduation ratio, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross primary graduation ratio. Female is the number of female graduates from the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the female population at the theoretical graduation age. The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school for the first time early/late or/and repeat a grade.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross primary graduation ratio, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross primary graduation ratio. Male is the number of male graduates from the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population at the theoretical graduation age. The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school for the first time early/late or/and repeat a grade.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross primary graduation ratio, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross primary graduation ratio. Total is the total number of graduates from the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population at the theoretical graduation age. The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school for the first time early/late or/and repeat a grade.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary completion rate, female (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Female is the total number of new female entrants in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as percentage of the total female population of the theoretical entrance age to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "gross intake rate to the last grade of primary." The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school late/early and/or repeat grades.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary completion rate, male (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Male is the total number of new male entrants in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as percentage of the total male population of the theoretical entrance age to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "gross intake rate to the last grade of primary." The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school late/early and/or repeat grades.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary completion rate, total (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary completion rate. Total is the total number of new entrants in the last grade of primary education, regardless of age, expressed as percentage of the total population of the theoretical entrance age to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "gross intake rate to the last grade of primary." The ratio can exceed 100% due to over-aged and under-aged children who enter primary school late/early and/or repeat grades.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary completion rate, total (% of relevant age group), path to goal
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This indicator is created for the use of DDP chart. Values are linear growth "path" to achieving the goal by 2015, given the initial value around 1990.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates

wb:indicator.wb:name: Drop-out rate (%), primary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Drop-out rate. Primary. Female is calculated by subtracting the female survival rate from 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Drop-out rate (%), primary, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Drop-out rate. Primary. Male is calculated by subtracting the male survival rate from 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Drop-out rate (%), primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Drop-out rate. Primary. Total is calculated by subtracting the survival rate from 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, duration (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of primary is the number of grades (years) in primary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, pupils
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in primary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in public and private primary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Student enrollment, primary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in primary. Public and private. All programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in public and private primary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, pupils (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Primary is the number of female students at the primary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) at the primary level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pupil-teacher ratio, primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Primary is the number of pupils enrolled in primary school divided by the number of primary school teachers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary. Total is the total enrollment in primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of official primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary, female (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary. Female is the total female enrollment in primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of official primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary, male (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Primary. Male is the total male enrollment in primary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of official primary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected primary completion rate, female (% of population at theoretical entrance age)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expected primary completion rate. Female is the total number of new female entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to reach the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the female population at the official entrance age to primary education in the same year. It is calculated by multiplying the gross intake ratio to the first grade of primary education by the survival rate to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "Expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary. Female."
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected primary completion rate, male (% of population at theoretical entrance age)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expected primary completion rate. Male is the total number of new male entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to reach the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the male population at the official entrance age to primary education in the same year. It is calculated by multiplying the gross intake ratio to the first grade of primary education by the survival rate to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "Expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary. Male."
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected primary completion rate (% of population at theoretical entrance age)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expected primary completion rate. Total is the total number of new entrants to the first grade of primary in a given year, regardless of age, who are expected to reach the last grade of primary education, regardless of repetition, expressed as a percentage of the population at the official entrance age to primary education in the same year. It is calculated by multiplying the gross intake ratio to the first grade of primary education by the survival rate to the last grade of primary. This indicator is also known as "Expected gross intake ratio to the last grade of primary. Total."
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education, female (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education, male (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education, total (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross intake ratio in first grade of primary education is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the official primary entrance age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Primary. Total is the ratio of children of the official primary school age who are enrolled in primary school to the total population of the official primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary, female (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Primary. Female is the ratio of female children of the official primary school age who are enrolled in primary school to the female population of the official primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary, male (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Primary. Male is the ratio of male children of the official primary school age who are enrolled in primary school to the male population of the official primary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net intake rate in grade 1, female (% of official school-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Female is the number of new female entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of the same age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net intake rate in grade 1, male (% of official school-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Male is the number of new male entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of the same age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net intake rate in grade 1 (% of official school-age population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net intake rate. Primary. Total is the number of new entrants in the first grade of primary education who are of the official primary school-entrance age, expressed as a percentage of the population of the same age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, primary, private (% of total primary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Primary is the enrolment in private primary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in primary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to grade 5, female (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 5. Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 5. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to grade 5, male (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 5. Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 5. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to grade 5, total (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to grade 5. Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach grade 5. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to last grade of primary, female (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of primary. Female is the share of female children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to last grade of primary, male (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of primary. Male is the share of male children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Persistence to last grade of primary, total (% of cohort)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Survival rate to last grade of primary. Total is the share of children enrolled in the first grade of primary school who eventually reach the last grade of primary. The estimate is calculated on the basis of the reconstructed cohort method, which uses data on enrolment and repeaters for two consecutive years.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, primary, female (% of female enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. All grades. Female is the number of female students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all female students enrolled in primary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of female repeaters in all grades of primary education by the total female enrolment of primary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, primary, male (% of male enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. All grades. Male is the number of male students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all male students enrolled in primary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of male repeaters in all grades of primary education by the total male enrolment of primary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, primary, total (% of total enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in primary. All grades. Total is the number of students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all students enrolled in primary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of repeaters in all grades of primary education by the total enrolment of primary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trained teachers in primary education, female (% of female teachers)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Primary. Female is the number of female teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female teachers at the primary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trained teachers in primary education, male (% of male teachers)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Primary. Male is the number of male teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at the primary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Trained teachers in primary education (% of total teachers)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Primary. Total is the number of teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the primary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers at the primary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, teachers
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private primary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in primary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private primary education institutions. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary education, teachers (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Primary is the number of female teachers at the primary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the primary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net enrollment rate, primary (% of primary school age children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net enrollment is the number of pupils of the school-age group for primary education, enrolled either in primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net enrollment rate, primary, female (% of primary school age children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net enrollment is the number of pupils of the school-age group for primary education, enrolled either in primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adjusted net enrollment rate, primary, male (% of primary school age children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adjusted net enrollment is the number of pupils of the school-age group for primary education, enrolled either in primary or secondary education, expressed as a percentage of the total population in that age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children out of school, primary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out-of-school children of primary school age. Total is the total number of primary-school-age children who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children out of school, primary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out-of-school children of primary school age. Female is the total number of female primary-school-age children who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children out of school, primary, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out-of-school children of primary school age. Male is the total number of male primary-school-age children who are not enrolled in either primary or secondary schools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected years of schooling
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: School life expectancy (years). Primary to tertiary. Total is the total number of years of schooling which a child of a certain age can expect to receive in the future, assuming that the probability of his or her being enrolled in school at any particular age is equal to the current enrollment ratio for that age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected years of schooling, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expected years of schooling, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expected years of schooling, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Expected years of schooling, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary school starting age (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Entrance age of 2A lower secondary is the age at which students would enter lower secondary education, assuming they had started at the official entrance age for the lowest level of education, had studied full-time throughout and had progressed through the system without repeating or skipping a grade.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary completion rate, female (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Lower secondary completion rate is the percentage of children who are completing the last year of lower secondary education. It is calculated by taking the total number of students in the last grade of lower secondary education, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official completion age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary completion rate, male (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Lower secondary completion rate is the percentage of children who are completing the last year of lower secondary education. It is calculated by taking the total number of students in the last grade of lower secondary education, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official completion age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lower secondary completion rate, total (% of relevant age group)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Lower secondary completion rate is the percentage of children who are completing the last year of lower secondary education. It is calculated by taking the total number of students in the last grade of lower secondary education, minus the number of repeaters in that grade, divided by the total number of children of official completion age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) Institute for Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, duration (years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of secondary education is the number of grades (years) in secondary education (ISCED 2 & 3).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Duration of 2A lower secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of 2A lower secondary is the number of grades (years) in 2A lower secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Duration of education, upper secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Duration of 3A upper secondary is the number of grades (years) in 3A upper secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, pupils
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Student enrollment, secondary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. All programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vocational and Technical enrollment (% of total secondary enrollment), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in secondary (ISCED 2 and 3) as % of total secondary enrolment (ISCED 2 and 3), female is the percentage of all female lower and upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female students who are enrolled in lower and upper secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, pupils (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total secondary. All programmes is the number of female students enrolled in all secondary education programmes expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) enrolled at the secondary education level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, general pupils
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. General programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in general programmes at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, general pupils, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. General programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in general programmes at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, general pupils (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total secondary. General programmes is the number of female students enrolled in general programmes at the secondary education level expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) enrolled in general programmes at the secondary education level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vocational and Technical enrollment (% of total secondary enrollment), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in secondary (ISCED 2 and 3) as % of total secondary enrolment (ISCED 2 and 3), male is the percentage of all male lower and upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male students who are enrolled in lower and upper secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pupil-teacher ratio, secondary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pupil-teacher ratio. Secondary is the number of pupils enrolled in secondary school divided by the number of secondary school teachers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, vocational pupils
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. Technical/vocational programmes. Total is the total number of students enrolled in technical/vocational programmes at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, vocational pupils, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total secondary. Public and private. Technical/vocational programmes. Female is the total number of female students enrolled in technical/vocational programmes at public and private secondary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, vocational pupils (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total secondary. Technical/vocational programmes is the number of female students enrolled in technical/vocational programmes at the secondary education level expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) enrolled in technical/vocational programmes at the secondary education level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vocational and Technical enrollment (% of total secondary enrollment), total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Technical/vocational enrolment in secondary (ISCED 2 and 3) as % of total secondary enrolment (ISCED 2 and 3) is the percentage of all lower and upper secondary students enrolled in technical/vocational education programs including teacher training, expressed as a percentage of the total number of students who are enrolled in lower and upper secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Secondary. All programmes. Total is the total enrollment in secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the population of official secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary, female (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Secondary. All programmes. Female is the total female enrollment in secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of official secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrollment rate (%), lower secondary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Lower secondary. All programmes. Total is the total enrollment in lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of official lower secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrollment rate (%), lower secondary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Lower secondary. All programmes. Female is the total female enrollment in lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of official lower secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrollment rate (%), lower secondary, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Lower secondary. All programmes. Male is the total male enrollment in lower secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of official lower secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary, male (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Secondary. All programmes. Male is the total male enrollment in secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of official secondary education age. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrollment rate (%), upper secondary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes. Total is the total enrollment in upper secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of official upper secondary education age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes. Female is the total female enrollment in upper secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the female population of official upper secondary education age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Upper secondary. All programmes. Male is the total male enrollment in upper secondary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the male population of official upper secondary education age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Secondary. All programmes. Total is the ratio of children of the official secondary school age who are enrolled in secondary school to the population of the official secondary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary, female (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Secondary. All programmes. Female is the ratio of female children of the official secondary school age who are enrolled in secondary school to the female population of the official secondary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary, male (% net)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net enrolment rate. Secondary. All programmes. Male is the ratio of male children of the official secondary school age who are enrolled in secondary school to the male population of the official secondary school age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, secondary, private (% of total secondary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Secondary is the enrolment in private secondary schools expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in secondary schools. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities. A high percentage indicates strong involvement of the non-governmental sector (including religious bodies, other organizations, associations, communities, private enterprises or persons) in providing organized educational programmes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Progression to secondary school, female (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transition from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2), general programmes (%). Female is the number of new female entrants to the first grade of secondary education (general programmes only) in a given year, expressed as a percentage of the number of female pupils enrolled in the final grade of primary education in the previous year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Progression to secondary school, male (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transition from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2), general programmes (%). Male is the number of new male entrants to the first grade of secondary education (general programmes only) in a given year, expressed as a percentage of the number of male pupils enrolled in the final grade of primary education in the previous year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Progression to secondary school (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transition from primary (ISCED 1) to secondary (ISCED 2), general programmes (%). Total is the number of new entrants to the first grade of secondary education (general programmes only) in a given year, expressed as a percentage of the number of pupils enrolled in the final grade of primary education in the previous year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, secondary, female (% of female enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. All grades. Female is the number of female students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all female students enrolled in secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of female repeaters in all grades of secondary education by the total female enrolment of secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, secondary, male (% of male enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. All grades.
