Male is the number of male students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all male students enrolled in secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of male repeaters in all grades of secondary education by the total male enrolment of secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Repeaters, secondary, total (% of total enrollment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of repeaters in secondary. All grades. Total is the number of students enrolled in the same grade as in the previous year, as a percentage of all students enrolled in secondary school. It is calculated by dividing the sum of repeaters in all grades of secondary education by the total enrolment of secondary education and multiplying the result by 100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers (% trained), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Total secondary. Female is the number of female teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of female teachers at the secondary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers (% trained), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Total secondary. Male is the number of male teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of male teachers at the secondary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers (% trained)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of trained teachers. Secondary (ISCED 2 and 3). Total is the number of teachers who have received the minimum organized teacher training (pre-service or in-service) required for teaching at the secondary level in the given country, expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers at the secondary level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Secondary education, teachers (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Secondary is the number of female teachers at the secondary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the secondary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in total secondary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Male is the total number of male teachers in public and private secondary education institutions (ISCED 2 and 3). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Female is the total number of female graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the female population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Male is the total number of male graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the male population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross tertiary graduation ratio (first degree), total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross completion ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5A) first degree. Total is the total number of female graduates in tertiary ISCED 5A programmes (first degree) expressed as a percentage of the total population of the age where they theoretically finish the most common first degree programme in the given country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Student enrollment, tertiary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Total is the total number of students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Student enrollment, tertiary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Female is the total number of female students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Girls enrollment share (%), tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female students. Total tertiary is the number of female students at the tertiary education level (ISCED 5 and 6) expressed as a percentage of the total number of students (male and female) at the tertiary education level in a given school year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Student enrollment, tertiary, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Enrolment in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part time. Male is the total number of male students enrolled at public and private tertiary education institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, tertiary (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Total is the total enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, tertiary, female (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Female is the total female enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total female population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: School enrollment, tertiary, male (% gross)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. Tertiary (ISCED 5 and 6). Male is the total male enrollment in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6), regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total male population of the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates, tertiary, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total graduates in all programmes. Tertiary. Total is the total number of graduates in all programmes in tertiary institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in agriculture, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in agriculture is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied agriculture.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in agriculture (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in agriculture is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied agriculture.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in education, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in education is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in education (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in education is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied engineering, manufacturing and construction.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied engineering, manufacturing and construction.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates, tertiary, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total graduates in all programmes. Tertiary. Female is the total number of female graduates from all programmes at ISCED 5 and 6 tertiary institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in agriculture (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in agriculture (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in education (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in education (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female tertiary graduates as percentage of all graduates in engineering, manufacturing and construction
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in health (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in health (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in humanities and arts (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in humanities and arts (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in science (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female tertiary graduates as percentage of all graduates in science
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in social science, business and law (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in social science, business and law (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female share of graduates in services (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female share of graduates in services (%, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Girls graduates share (%), tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female graduates in tertiary education (ISCED 5 and 6) is the number of females graduating from ISCED 5 and 6 expressed as a percentage of the total number of ISCED 5 and 6 tertiary graduates (male and female).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in health, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in health and welfare is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied health and welfare.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in health (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in health and welfare is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied health and welfare.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in humanities and arts, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in humanities and arts is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied humanities and arts.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in humanities and arts (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in humanities and arts is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied humanities and arts.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in unknown or unspecified fields, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in unspecified programmes is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied unspecified programmes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in unknown or unspecified fields (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in unspecified programmes is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied in unspecified programmes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in science, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in science is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied science.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in science (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in science is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied science.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in social science, business, law, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in social sciences, business and law is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied social sciences, business and law.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in social science, business, law (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in social sciences, business and law is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied social sciences, business and law.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in services, female (% of total female graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of female tertiary graduates in services is the share of all female tertiary graduates who studied services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Graduates in services (% of total graduates, tertiary)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of tertiary graduates in services is the share of all tertiary graduates who studied in the services field.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private enrollment share (%), tertiary
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of private enrolment. Tertiary is the enrolment in private tertiary institutions expressed as a percentage of total enrolment (public and private) in tertiary institutions. 'Private' refers to all educational institutions not operated by a public authority, regardless of whether they receive financial support from public authorities.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tertiary education, teachers
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Total is the total number of teachers in public and private tertiary education institutions (ISCED 5 & 6). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Teaching staff in total tertiary. Public and private. Full and part-time. All programmes. Female is the total number of female teachers in public and private tertiary education institutions (ISCED 5 & 6). Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tertiary education, teachers (% female)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage female teachers. Tertiary is the number of female teachers at the tertiary level expressed as a percentage of the total number of teachers (male and female) at the tertiary level in a given school year. Teachers are persons employed full time or part time in an official capacity to guide and direct the learning experience of pupils and students, irrespective of their qualifications or the delivery mechanism, i.e. face-to-face and/or at a distance. This definition excludes educational personnel who have no active teaching duties (e.g. headmasters, headmistresses or principals who do not teach) and persons who work occasionally or in a voluntary capacity in educational institutions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gross enrolment ratio. All levels combined (except pre-primary). Total is the total enrollment in primary, secondary and tertiary education, regardless of age, expressed as a percentage of the total population of primary school age, secondary school age, and the five-year age group following on from secondary school leaving. GER can exceed 100% due to the inclusion of over-aged and under-aged students because of early or late school entrance and grade repetition.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public current education expenditure, primary (% of current education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Primary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to primary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public current education expenditure, secondary (% of current education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Secondary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to secondary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public current education expenditure, tertiary (% of current education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure on education by level. Tertiary is the share of public current education expenditure that is devoted to tertiary education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public current education expenditure (% of total education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public current expenditure on education as % of total public education expenditure is the recurrent public education expenditure expressed as a percentage of total public expenditure on education (current and capital) in a given financial year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expenditure per student, primary (% of GDP per capita)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Primary is the total public expenditure per student in primary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of public expenditure for primary education (% of public education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in primary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for primary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Spending on teaching materials, primary (% of primary expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in primary education. Teaching materials is the share of public current expenditure for primary education devoted to teaching materials.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expenditure per student, secondary (% of GDP per capita)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Secondary is the total public expenditure per student in secondary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of public expenditure for secondary education (% of public education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in secondary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for secondary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Spending on teaching materials, secondary (% of secondary expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage distribution of public current expenditure by purpose in secondary education. Teaching materials is the share of public current expenditure for secondary education devoted to teaching materials.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Teachers' salaries (% of current education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure on teachers salaries as a % of current education expenditures on public institutions. All Levels is spending on teacher salaries expressed as a percentage of the total current expenditures on education for all educational levels.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Expenditure per student, tertiary (% of GDP per capita)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. Tertiary is the total public expenditure per student in tertiary education as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of expenditure for tertiary education (% of total education expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Educational expenditure in tertiary as % of total educational expenditure is the percentage of public education expenditure for tertiary education. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private) and education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities). In some instances data on public expenditure on education refers only to the ministry of education, excluding other ministries that spend a part of their budget on educational activities at a given level of education.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public spending on education, total (% of government expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of total government expenditure is the total public education expenditure (current and capital) expressed as a percentage of total government expenditure for all sectors in a given financial year. Public education expenditure includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration, and subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public spending on education, total (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of GDP is the total public expenditure (current and capital) on education expressed as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) in a given year. Public expenditure on education includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration, and transfers/subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public education expenditure, % of GNI
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure on education as % of GNI is the total public expenditure on education (current and capital) expressed as a percentage of the Gross National Income (GNI) in a given financial year. GNI is also referred to as Gross National Product (GNP). Public expenditure on education includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration and subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Public education expenditure per student (% of p.c. GDP), all levels
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public expenditure per pupil as a % of GDP per capita. All levels is the total public expenditure per student as a percentage of GDP per capita. Public expenditure (current and capital) includes government spending on educational institutions (both public and private), education administration as well as subsidies for private entities (students/households and other privates entities).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female legislators, senior officials and managers (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female legislators, senior officials and managers (% of total) refers to the share of legislators, senior officials and managers who are female.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Proportion of women in ministerial level positions (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Proportion of women in ministerial level positions (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) (www.ipu.org)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Proportion of seats held by women in national parliaments (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Women in parliaments are the percentage of parliamentary seats in a single or lower chamber held by women.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Inter-Parliamentary Union (IPU) (www.ipu.org)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Female professional and technical workers (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female professional and technical workers (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Gender, Institutions and Development Database, Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), web site: http://www.oecd.org/document/16/0,3343,en_2649_33935_39323280_1_1_1_1,00.html.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she argues with him (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she argues with him.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she burns the food (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she burns the food.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she goes out without telling him (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she goes out without telling him.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she neglects the children (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she neglects the children.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife (any of five reasons) (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner for any of the following five reasons: argues with him; refuses to have sex; burns the food; goes out without telling him; or when she neglects the children.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women who believe a husband is justified in beating his wife when she refuses sex with him (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women ages 15-49 who believe a husband/partner is justified in hitting or beating his wife/partner when she refuses sex with him.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys (DHS) and Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys (MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Problems in accessing health care (not wanting to go alone) (% of women): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. The types of problem specified are; knowing where to go for treatment, getting permission to go for treatment, getting money for treatment, distance to health facility, having to take transport, not wanting to go alone, and concern there may not be a female provider.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Problems in accessing health care: Percentage of women who report they have big problems in accessing health care for themselves when they are sick, by type of problem. The types of problem specified are; knowing where to go for treatment, getting permission to go for treatment, getting money for treatment, distance to health facility, having to take transport, not wanting to go alone, and concern there may not be a female provider.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of anemia among children (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of anemia, children under age 5, is the percentage of children under age 5 whose hemoglobin level is less than 110 grams per liter at sea level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: 1. WHO. Global anemia prevalence and trends 1995-2011. Geneva: World Health Organization; forthcoming. 2. Stevens GA, Finucane MM, De-Regil LM, et al. Global, regional, and national trends in hemoglobin concentration and prevalence of total and severe anemia in children and pregnant and non-pregnant women for 1995-2011: a systematic analysis of population-representative data. The Lancet Global Health 2013; 1(1): e16-e25.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of anemia among non-pregnant women (% of women ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of anemia, non-pregnant women, is the percentage of non-pregnant women whose hemoglobin level is less than 120 grams per liter at sea level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Worldwide Prevalence of Anemia.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use, population ages 15-24, female (% of females ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use is the percentage of the population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use, population ages 15-24, male (% of males ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use is the percentage of the population ages 15-24 who used a condom at last intercourse in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use with non regular partner, % adults(15-49), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use at last high-risk sex is the percentage of the population ages 15-49 who used a condom at last intercourse with a non-marital and non-cohabiting sexual partner in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys from national sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Condom use with non regular partner, % adults(15-49), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Condom use at last high-risk sex is the percentage of the population ages 15-49 who used a condom at last intercourse with a non-marital and non-cohabiting sexual partner in the last 12 months.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys from national sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Communicable diseases and maternal, prenatal and nutrition conditions include infectious and parasitic diseases, respiratory infections, and nutritional deficiencies such as underweight and stunting.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of infant deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of infants dying before reaching one year of age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by injury (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Injuries include unintentional and intentional injuries.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of under-five deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of children dying before reaching age five.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Cause of death, by non-communicable diseases (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Cause of death refers to the share of all deaths for all ages by underlying causes. Non-communicable diseases include cancer, diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular diseases, digestive diseases, skin diseases, musculoskeletal diseases, and congenital anomalies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Derived based on the data from WHO's World Health Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of neonatal deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adults (ages 15+) living with HIV
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults living with HIV refers to the number of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: AIDS estimated deaths (UNAIDS estimates)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: AIDS deaths are the estimated number of adults and children who died due to AIDS-related causes.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Women's share of population ages 15+ living with HIV (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Female rate is as a percentage of the total population ages 15+ who are living with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV prevalence rate, adult 15-49 years (%; high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV based on a high estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV prevalence rate, adult 15-49 years (%; low estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV based on a low estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of HIV, total (% of population ages 15-49)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV refers to the percentage of people ages 15-49 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, female child (per 1,000 female children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, female child (per 1,000 female children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, male child (per 1,000 male children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, male child (per 1,000 male children age one)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child mortality rate is the probability of dying between the exact ages of one and five, if subject to current age-specific mortality rates. The probability is expressed as a rate per 1,000.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International, Multiple Indicators Cluster Surveys by UNICEF, Reproductive Health Surveys by U.S. Center for Disease Control, and Family Health Surveys by Pan Arab Project for Family Health. See footnotes for a source.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, under-5 (per 1,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-five mortality rate is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, under-5, female (per 1,000)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-five mortality rate, female is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn female baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to female age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, under-5, male (per 1,000)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-five mortality rate, male is the probability per 1,000 that a newborn male baby will die before reaching age five, if subject to male age-specific mortality rates of the specified year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Under-5 mortality rate: Number of deaths to children under age five years per 1000 live births, based on experience during the reference period before the survey. The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q2
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile

The reference period is ten years preceding the survey for DHS surveys, and the reference period varies for MICS surveys (often three to five years preceding the survey).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Under-5 mortality rate (per 1,000 live births): Q5 (highest)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mortality rate, neonatal (per 1,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Neonatal mortality rate is the number of neonates dying before reaching 28 days of age, per 1,000 live births in a given year.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Estimates developed by the UN Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UNICEF, WHO, World Bank, UN DESA Population Division) at www.childmortality.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source, rural (% of rural population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source. The improved drinking water source includes piped water on premises (piped household water connection located inside the user’s dwelling, plot or yard), and other improved drinking water sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source, urban (% of urban population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source. The improved drinking water source includes piped water on premises (piped household water connection located inside the user’s dwelling, plot or yard), and other improved drinking water sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved water source (% of population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to an improved water source refers to the percentage of the population using an improved drinking water source. The improved drinking water source includes piped water on premises (piped household water connection located inside the user’s dwelling, plot or yard), and other improved drinking water sources (public taps or standpipes, tube wells or boreholes, protected dug wells, protected springs, and rainwater collection).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children (0-14) living with HIV
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children living with HIV refers to the number of children ages 0-14 who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of HIV, young women 15-24 years (%; high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV, female refers to the percentage of females ages 15-24 who are infected with HIV based the high estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of HIV, young women 15-24 years (%; low estimate)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of HIV, female (% ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Comprehensive correct knowledge of HIV/AIDS, ages 15-24, female (2 prevent ways and reject 3 misconceptions)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The percent of female respondents ages 15-24 who correctly identify the two major ways of preventing the sexual transmission of HIV (using condoms and limiting sex to one faithful, uninfected partner), who reject the two most common local misconceptions about HIV transmission, and who know that a healthy-looking person can have HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of HIV, young men 15-24 years (%; high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV, male refers to the percentage of females ages 15-24 who are infected with HIV based the high estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of HIV is the percentage of people who are infected with HIV. Youth rates are as a percentage of the relevant age group.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antiretroviral therapy coverage (% of people living with HIV)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Antiretroviral therapy coverage indicates the percentage of all people living with HIV who are receiving antiretroviral therapy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: AIDS deaths in adults and children (high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Deaths due to HIV/AIDS are the estimated number of adults and children that have died in a specific year based in the modeling of HIV surveillance data using standard and appropriate tools.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Orphans 0-17 years currently living (high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: AIDS orphans are the estimated number of children who have lost their mother or both parents to AIDS before age 17 since the epidemic began in 1990. Some of the orphaned children included in this cumulative total are no longer alive; others are no longer under age 17.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Orphans 0-17 years currently living (low estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: AIDS orphans are the estimated number of children who have lost their mother or both parents to AIDS before age 17 since the epidemic began in 1990. Some of the orphaned children included in this cumulative total are no longer alive; others are no longer under age 17.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Orphans 0-17 years currently living
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: AIDS orphans are the estimated number of children who have lost their mother or both parents to AIDS before age 17 since the epidemic began in 1990. Some of the orphaned children included in this cumulative total are no longer alive; others are no longer under age 17.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children orphaned by HIV/AIDS
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of children orphaned by HIV/AIDS is the estimated number of children who have lost their mother or both parents to AIDS before age 15 since the epidemic began. Some of the orphaned children included in this cumulative total are no longer alive; others are no longer under age 15.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Numerator: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission. Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months. Ranges are presented for countries with low and concentrated epidemics. The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV. All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted. All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum). The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

wb:indicator.wb:name: HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals, using WHO/UNAIDS methodology (%; low estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission. Numerator: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission. Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months. Ranges are presented for countries with low and concentrated epidemics. The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV. All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted. All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum). The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of HIV positive pregnant women receiving antiretrovirals
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of HIV-infected pregnant women who received antiretrovirals during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission. The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

Denominator: Estimated number of HIV-infected pregnant women in the last 12 months. The purpose of this indicator is to assess progress in preventing vertical transmission of HIV. All data reflect values representing 12 month period ending December 2007 which have been reconciled between reporting country and UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF, unless otherwise noted. All analysis of this indicator, including quoted country figures, reflect numerators which have gone through a tri agency reconciliation (UNAIDS/WHO/UNICEF) process and denominators which have been estimated directly from the UNAIDS/WHO Reference group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections methodology (Spectrum). The reconciliation process ensured all agencies reported the same country endorsed figure which was the most recent and met the definition of HIV-infected women receiving antiretroviral drugs over the last 12 months, and thus reflect a full year. Every effort was made in cases of discrepancy across the three agencies to obtain approval from the country on a final indicator value.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: http://data.unaids.org/pub/GlobalReport/2008/

wb:indicator.wb:name: Adults (ages 15+) and children (0-14 years) living with HIV
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Adults and children living with HIV refers to the number of people ages 0-49 (adult ages 15-49 and children ages 0-14) who are infected with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total (high estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total (low estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: People living with HIV/AIDS, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Estimated total number of people with HIV/AIDS is the number of people living with HIV. Depending on the reliability of the data available, there may be more or less uncertainty surrounding each estimate.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS and the WHO's Report on the Global AIDS Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vaccinations (all vaccinations) (% of children ages 12-23 months): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vaccinations: Percentage of children 12-23 months who have received specific vaccines by the time of the survey (according to the vaccination card or the mother's report). Children with all vaccinations refer children who have received BCG, measles, and three doses each of DPT and polio vaccine (excluding polio 0). Some MICS surveys refer children in different age groups (e.g. 18-29 months, or 15-26 months).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, HepB3 (% of one-year-old children)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization rate, hepatitis B is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, Hib3 (% of children ages 12-23 months)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization measures the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized against Hib3 after receiving three doses of Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/

wb:indicator.wb:name: Immunization, BCG (% of one-year-old children)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Child immunization rate, Polio is the percentage of children ages 12-23 months who received vaccinations before 12 months or at any time before the survey. A child is considered adequately immunized after three doses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization_monitoring/routine/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Hospital beds (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Hospital beds include inpatient beds available in public, private, general, and specialized hospitals and rehabilitation centers. In most cases beds for both acute and chronic care are included.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Data are from the World Health Organization, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Community health workers (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Community health workers include various types of community health aides, many with country-specific occupational titles such as community health officers, community health-education workers, family health workers, lady health visitors and health extension package workers.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, OECD, supplemented by country data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Nurses and midwives (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Nurses and midwives include professional nurses, professional midwives, auxiliary nurses, auxiliary midwives, enrolled nurses, enrolled midwives and other associated personnel, such as dental nurses and primary care nurses.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Atlas of the Health Workforce. For latest updates and metadata, see http://apps.who.int/globalatlas/.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Physicians (per 1,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Physicians include generalist and specialist medical practitioners.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Atlas of the Health Workforce. For latest updates and metadata, see http://apps.who.int/globalatlas/.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Reported clinical malaria cases (total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of clinical malaria cases reported are the sum of cases confirmed by slide examination or RDT and probable and unconfirmed cases (cases that were not tested but treated as malaria). NMCPs often collect data on the number of suspected cases, those t
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization Global Malaria Programme (http://www.who.int/malaria/world_malaria_report_2009/all_mal2009_annexes.pdf)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Deaths among children under five years of age due to malaria (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: "Malaria mortality is the percentage of deaths due to malaria among children under five years. Malaria was the underlying cause of death, that is, the disease which initiated the train of morbid events leading directly to death. This is the distribution of main causes of death among children aged < 5 years, expressed as percentage of total deaths. "
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organisation.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Reported malaria deaths (total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Reported malaria deaths include all deaths in health facilities that are attributed to malaria, whether or not confirmed by microscopy or by RDT. Deaths reported before 2000 can be probable and confirmed or only confirmed deaths depending on the country
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization Global Malaria Programme (http://www.who.int/malaria/world_malaria_report_2009/all_mal2009_annexes.pdf)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Households with one or more insect-treated mosquito net (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of households owning at least one insecticide-treated bednet (ITN).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: DHS, MICS, MIS or MoH surveys.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Mosquito net use by children (any mosquito net) (% of children under 5): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Mosquito net use by children: Percentage of children under age five years who slept under any mosquito net (treated or untreated), and an insecticide-treated net (ITN) the night before the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Household posession of mosquito nets (any type of mosquito net) (% of households): Q1 (lowest)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Household possession of mosquito nets: Percentage of households with at least one any type of mosquito net (treated or untreated), and insecticide-treated net (ITN).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Use of preventive treatment for malaria (% of pregnant women)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Use of preventive treatment for malaria shows the prophylactic use of antimalarial drugs and use of Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) by women during pregnancy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Use of Intermittent Preventive Treatment of malaria, 2+ doses of SP/Fansidar (% of pregnant women)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage of women with a live birth in the recent years preceding the survey who received 2+ doses of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP/Fansidar), at least one during an antenatal care visit. Intermittent Preventive Treatment (IPT) is preventive treatment with SP/Fansidar during an antenatal care (ANC) visit treatment with a dose of sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine (SP/Fansidar) to pregnant women at each scheduled antenatal visit after the first trimester, but not more frequently than once a month.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF Childinfo, Multiple Indicator Cluster Surveys, Demographic and Health Surveys.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Anti-malarial drug use by pregnant women: Percentage of women with a live birth in the two years preceding the survey who during the pregnancy took any antimalarial drug for prevention, and who took SP/Fansidar two or more doses.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children with fever receiving antimalarial drugs (% of children under age 5 with fever)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malaria treatment refers to the percentage of children under age five who were ill with fever in the last two weeks and received any appropriate (locally defined) anti-malarial drugs.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of maternal deaths
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternal mortality deaths is the number of women who die during pregnancy and childbirth.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2013. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of weeks of maternity leave
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of weeks of maternity leave
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (1 in: rate varies by country)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2013. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Lifetime risk of maternal death (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Life time risk of maternal death is the probability that a 15-year-old female will die eventually from a maternal cause assuming that current levels of fertility and mortality (including maternal mortality) do not change in the future, taking into account competing causes of death.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2013. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Maternal leave benefits (% of wages paid in covered period)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternal leave benefits (% of wages paid in covered period)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, World's Women.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of anemia among pregnant women (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of anemia, pregnant women, is the percentage of pregnant women whose hemoglobin level is less than 110 grams per liter at sea level.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Worldwide Prevalence of Anemia.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antiretroviral therapy coverage (% of pregnant women living with HIV)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The percentage of pregnant women living with HIV who received the most effective antiretroviral regimens as recommended by WHO during the last 12 months to reduce mother-to-child transmission.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNAIDS estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking prevalence, females (% of adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, female is the percentage of women ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking (% of women): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Smoking: Percentage of all women who smoke cigarettes, pipe or other tobacco.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking (% of women): Q5 (highest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Smoking: Percentage of all women who smoke cigarettes, pipe or other tobacco.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Smoking prevalence, males (% of adults)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of smoking, male is the percentage of men ages 15 and over who smoke any form of tobacco, including cigarettes, cigars, and pipes, and excluding smokeless tobacco. Data include daily and non-daily smoking.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO Report on the Global Tobacco Epidemic.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved sanitation facilities (% of population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. The improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved sanitation facilities, rural (% of rural population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. The improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Improved sanitation facilities, urban (% of urban population with access)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Access to improved sanitation facilities refers to the percentage of the population using improved sanitation facilities. The improved sanitation facilities include flush/pour flush (to piped sewer system, septic tank, pit latrine), ventilated improved pit (VIP) latrine, pit latrine with slab, and composting toilet.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO/UNICEF Joint Monitoring Programme (JMP) for Water Supply and Sanitation (http://www.wssinfo.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Components of antenatal care (received iron tablets or syrup) (% of women with a birth): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Components of antenatal care: Percentage of women with a live birth in the three years preceding the survey who received iron tablets or syrup during pregnancy before the most recent birth.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Components of antenatal care (received iron tablets or syrup) (% of women with a birth): Q3
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Components of antenatal care: Percentage of women with a live birth in the three years preceding the survey who received iron tablets or syrup during pregnancy before the most recent birth.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care of at least four visits (% of pregnant women)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Pregnant women receiving prenatal care, at least four times, are the percentage of women attended at least four times during pregnancy by skilled health personnel for reasons related to pregnancy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by Macro International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antenatal care (any skilled personnel) (% of women with a birth): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Antenatal care: Percentage of women with one or more live births in the three (one, two) years preceding the survey who have received at least one antenatal care during pregnancy before the most recent birth from any skilled personnel and from a doctor. If the respondent mentioned more than one provider, only the most qualified provider is considered. The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Antenatal care (any skilled personnel) (% of women with a birth): Q2
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Antenatal care: Percentage of women with one or more live births in the three (one, two) years preceding the survey who have received at least one antenatal care during pregnancy before the most recent birth from any skilled personnel and from a doctor. If the respondent mentioned more than one provider, only the most qualified provider is considered. The DHS surveys refer births in the three years preceding the survey, the MICS2 surveys refer births in the one year preceding the survey, and the MICS3 surveys refer births in the two years preceding the survey.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Low-birthweight babies (% of births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Low-birthweight babies are newborns weighing less than 2,500 grams, with the measurement taken within the first hours of life, before significant postnatal weight loss has occurred.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Diabetes prevalence refers to the percentage of people ages 20-79 who have type 1 or type 2 diabetes.
