wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5) (% of women): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5): Percentage of women whose body mass index (BMI) is less than 18.5 for women with births in the three years preceding the survey. The BMI is the ratio of the weight in kilograms to the square of the height in meters (kg/m2). The BMI excludes pregnant women and those who are less than three months postpartum.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5) (% of women): Q2

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5) (% of women): Q4
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5): Percentage of women whose body mass index (BMI) is less than 18.5 for women with births in the three years preceding the survey. The BMI is the ratio of the weight in kilograms to the square of the height in meters (kg/m2). The BMI excludes pregnant women and those who are less than three months postpartum.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5) (% of women): Q5 (highest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished women (BMI is less than 18.5): Percentage of women whose body mass index (BMI) is less than 18.5 for women with births in the three years preceding the survey. The BMI is the ratio of the weight in kilograms to the square of the height in meters (kg/m2). The BMI excludes pregnant women and those who are less than three months postpartum.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age, female (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age, male (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished children (underweight, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished children (underweight, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q2
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile

Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, weight for age (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for age is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malaria cases reported
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Reported cases of malaria are the sum of confirmed cases of malaria (confirmed by slide examination or RDT) and probable (unconfirmed) cases of malaria (cases that were not tested but treated as malaria). Predominant type of statistics: unadjusted.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Maternal mortality ratio (modeled estimate, per 100,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die during pregnancy and childbirth, per 100,000 live births. The data are estimated with a regression model using information on fertility, birth attendants, and HIV prevalence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO, UNICEF, UNFPA, The World Bank, and the United Nations Population Division. Trends in Maternal Mortality: 1990 to 2013. Geneva, World Health Organization, 2014

wb:indicator.wb:name: Maternal mortality ratio (national estimate, per 100,000 live births)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Maternal mortality ratio is the number of women who die from pregnancy-related causes while pregnant or within 42 days of pregnancy termination per 100,000 live births.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Diarrhea treatment (% of children under 5 receiving oral rehydration and continued feeding)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children with diarrhea who received oral rehydration and continued feeding refer to the percentage of children under age five with diarrhea in the two weeks prior to the survey who received either oral rehydration therapy or increased fluids, with continued feeding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNICEF, State of the World's Children, Childinfo, and Demographic and Health Surveys by ICF International.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Treatment of diarrhea (ORS, RHS or increased fluids) (% of children under 5): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Treatment of diarrhea (ORS, RHS or increased fluids): Percentage of children under age five years with diarrhea in the two weeks preceding the survey who received oral rehydration solution (ORS), recommended home solution (RHS) or increased fluids.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of overweight, female (% of female population ages 15+)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of overweight, female (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of overweight children is the percentage of children under age 5 whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations above the median for the international reference population of the corresponding age as established by the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, height for age, female (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age (stunting) is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, height for age, male (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age (stunting) is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished children (stunting, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q3
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished children (stunting, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q4
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnourished children (stunting, -2SD) (% of children under 5): Q5 (highest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). Each index is expressed in terms of the number of standard deviation (SD) units from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. Children are classified as malnourished if their z-scores are below minus two or minus three standard deviations (-2 SD or -3 SD) from the median of the WHO Child Growth Standards. The percentage below -2 SD includes children who are below -3 SD.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Household Surveys (DHS, MICS)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Malnutrition prevalence, height for age (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prevalence of child malnutrition is the percentage of children under age 5 whose height for age (stunting) is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59 months. For children up to two years old height is measured by recumbent length. For older children height is measured by stature while standing. The data are based on the WHO's new child growth standards released in 2006.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of wasting, female (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of wasting, male (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than two standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Malnourished children: Percentage of children under age five years who are classified as undernourished according to three anthropometric indices of nutritional status: height-for-age (stunting), weight-for-age (underweight) and weight-for-height (wasting). wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height, female (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Severe wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height, male (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Severe wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Prevalence of severe wasting, weight for height (% of children under 5)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Severe wasting prevalence is the proportion of children under five whose weight for height is more than three standard deviations below the median for the international reference population ages 0-59.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Database on Child Growth and Malnutrition. Country-level data are unadjusted data from national surveys, and thus may not be comparable across countries. Adjusted, comparable data are available at http://www.who.int/nutgrowthdb/en. Aggregation is based on UNICEF, WHO, and the World Bank harmonized dataset (adjusted, comparable data) and methodology.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis treatment success rate (% of registered cases)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis treatment success rate is the percentage of new, registered smear-positive (infectious) cases that were cured or in which a full course of treatment was completed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis case detection rate (%, all forms)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis case detection rate (all forms) is the percentage of newly notified tuberculosis cases (including relapses) to estimated incident cases (case detection, all forms).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Incidence of tuberculosis (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases. Incidence includes patients with HIV.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Incidence of tuberculosis, high uncertainty bound (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Incidence of tuberculosis, low uncertainty bound (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Incidence of tuberculosis is the estimated number of new pulmonary, smear positive, and extra-pulmonary tuberculosis cases.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis death rate (per 100,000 people)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis death rate is the number of deaths from tuberculosis per 100,000 population. Tuberculosis death rate excludes patients with HIV. Estimates for all years are re-calculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Deaths due to tuberculosis among HIV-negative people, high uncertainty bound (per 100,000 population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The estimated number of deaths attributable to tuberculosis (TB) in a given time period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Deaths due to tuberculosis among HIV-negative people, low uncertainty bound (per 100,000 population)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The estimated number of deaths attributable to tuberculosis (TB) in a given time period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate (per 100,000 population, WHO)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tuberculosis prevalence rate is the number of illnesses, accidents or sick persons per 100,000 population, without distinction between new and old cases. Prevalence includes patients with HIV. Estimates for all years are re-calculated as new information becomes available and techniques are refined, so they may differ from those published previously.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate, high uncertainty bound (per 1000,000 population, WHO)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The number of cases of tuberculosis (all forms) in a population at a given point in time (the middle of the calendar year), expressed as the rate per 100 000 population. It is sometimes referred to as "point prevalence" high uncertainty bound. Estimates include cases of TB in people with HIV. Published values are rounded to three significant figures. Uncertainty bounds are provided in addition to best estimates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tuberculosis prevalence rate, low uncertainty bound (per 1000,000 population, WHO)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The number of cases of tuberculosis (all forms) in a population at a given point in time (the middle of the calendar year), expressed as the rate per 100 000 population. It is sometimes referred to as "point prevalence" low uncertainty bound. Estimates include cases of TB in people with HIV. Published values are rounded to three significant figures. Uncertainty bounds are provided in addition to best estimates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization, Global Tuberculosis Control Report.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tetanus toxoid vaccination (% of live births): Q1 (lowest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percent distribution of last live births in the last three years preceding the survey for tetanus toxoid injections (two doses or more) given to the mother during pregnancy.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tetanus toxoid vaccination (% of live births): Q2
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percent distribution of last live births in the last three years preceding the survey for tetanus toxoid injections (two doses or more) given to the mother during pregnancy.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tetanus toxoid vaccination (% of live births): Q3
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percent distribution of last live births in the last three years preceding the survey for tetanus toxoid injections (two doses or more) given to the mother during pregnancy.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tetanus toxoid vaccination (% of live births): Q4
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percent distribution of last live births in the last three years preceding the survey for tetanus toxoid injections (two doses or more) given to the mother during pregnancy.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tetanus toxoid vaccination (% of live births): Q5 (highest)
wb:indicator.wb:source: Health Nutrition and Population Statistics by Wealth Quintile
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percent distribution of last live births in the last three years preceding the survey for tetanus toxoid injections (two doses or more) given to the mother during pregnancy.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Newborns protected against tetanus (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Newborns protected against tetanus are the percentage of births by women of child-bearing age who are immunized against tetanus.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: WHO and UNICEF (http://www.who.int/immunization/monitoring_surveillance/en/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: External resources for health (% of total expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: External resources for health are funds or services in kind that are provided by entities not part of the country in question. The resources may come from international organizations, other countries through bilateral arrangements, or foreign nongovernmental organizations. These resources are part of total health expenditure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of total expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households, including gratuities and in-kind payments, to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals, therapeutic appliances, and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Out-of-pocket health expenditure (% of private expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Out of pocket expenditure is any direct outlay by households, including gratuities and in-kind payments, to health practitioners and suppliers of pharmaceuticals, therapeutic appliances, and other goods and services whose primary intent is to contribute to the restoration or enhancement of the health status of individuals or population groups. It is a part of private health expenditure.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure per capita (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Government health expenditure per capita (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: General government expenditure corresponds to the consolidated outlays of all levels of government: territorial authorities (Central/Federal Government, Provincial/Regional/State/District authorities, Municipal/ Local governments), social security institutions and extra budgetary funds, including capital outlays. It is provided by the Central Bank/Ministry of Finance to the International Monetary Fund or by the United Nations Statistics Department.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure per capita, PPP (constant 2005 international $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditures as a ratio of total population. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation. Data are in international dollars converted using 2005 purchasing power parity (PPP) rates.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Private prepaid plans (% of private expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Prepaid and risk-pooling plans are the expenditure on health by private insurance institutions. Private insurance enrolment may be contractual or voluntary, and conditions and benefits or basket of benefits are agreed on a voluntary basis between the insurance agent and the beneficiaries. They are thus not controlled by government units for the purpose of providing social benefits to members.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, private (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Private health expenditure includes direct household (out-of-pocket) spending, private insurance, charitable donations, and direct service payments by private corporations.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of total health expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds. Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of government expenditure)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, public (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Public health expenditure consists of recurrent and capital spending from government (central and local) budgets, external borrowings and grants (including donations from international agencies and nongovernmental organizations), and social (or compulsory) health insurance funds.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Social Security expenditure on health (% government expenditure on health)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Social security funds comprise the expenditure on health by social security institutions. Social security or national health insurance schemes are imposed and controlled by government units for the purpose of providing social benefits to members of the community as a whole or to particular segments of the community. They include direct outlays to medical care providers and to suppliers of medical goods as well as reimbursements to households and the supply of services in kind to the enrollees.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/nha/country/en/)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Health expenditure, total (% of GDP)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total health expenditure is the sum of public and private health expenditure. It covers the provision of health services (preventive and curative), family planning activities, nutrition activities, and emergency aid designated for health but does not include provision of water and sanitation.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Health Organization National Health Account database (see http://apps.who.int/nha/database/DataExplorerRegime.aspx for the most recent updates).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Shrimp, Mexico, cents/kg, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Shrimp , (Mexico), west coast, frozen, white, No. 1, shell-on, headless, 26 to 30 count per pound, wholesale price at New York
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: US Department of Commerce, NOAA, Fishery Market News; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by second 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Income share held by third 20%
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Percentage share of income or consumption is the share that accrues to subgroups of population indicated by deciles or quintiles. Percentage shares by quintile may not sum to 100 because of rounding.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty headcount ratio at $2 a day (PPP) (% of population)

As a result of revisions in PPP exchange rates, poverty rates for individual countries cannot be compared with poverty rates reported in earlier editions.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at $2 a day (PPP) (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Poverty gap is the mean shortfall from the poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. Data for high-income economies are from the Luxembourg Income Study database. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Poverty gap at $2.5 a day (PPP) (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The mean shortfall from the $2.5 a day poverty line (counting the nonpoor as having zero shortfall), expressed as a percentage of the poverty line. This measure reflects the depth of poverty as well as its incidence.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:name: GINI index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Gini index measures the extent to which the distribution of income or consumption expenditure among individuals or households within an economy deviates from a perfectly equal distribution. A Lorenz curve plots the cumulative percentages of total income received against the cumulative number of recipients, starting with the poorest individual or household. The Gini index measures the area between the Lorenz curve and a hypothetical line of absolute equality, expressed as a percentage of the maximum area under the line. Thus a Gini index of 0 represents perfect equality, while an index of 100 implies perfect inequality.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Development Research Group. Data are based on primary household survey data obtained from government statistical agencies and World Bank country departments. For more information and methodology, please see PovcalNet (http://iresearch.worldbank.org/PovcalNet/index.htm).

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are compiled from official government sources or are computed by World Bank staff using national (i.e. country–specific) poverty lines.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank, Global Poverty Working Group. Data are based on World Bank's country poverty assessments and country Poverty Reduction Strategies.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Platts Metasl Week; Australian Minerals Economics Pty, Ltd., Silver World Supply & Demand, Thomson Reuters Datastream; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in agriculture (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes agriculture and hunting, forestry and logging, and fishing. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, agriculture, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, agriculture, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in agriculture (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Agriculture corresponds to division 1 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories A and B (ISIC revision 3) and includes hunting, forestry, and fishing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, male (%) (modeled ILO estimate)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment to population ratio, ages 15-24, total (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15-24 are generally considered the youth population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Share of women employed in the nonagricultural sector (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of women employed in the nonagricultural sector is the share of female workers in the nonagricultural sector (industry and services), expressed as a percentage of total employment in the nonagricultural sector. Industry includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, electricity, gas, and water, corresponding to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3). Services include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services-corresponding to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employers, female (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employers refers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced), and, in this capacity, have engaged, on a continuous basis, one or more persons to work for them as employee(s).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employers, male (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employers refers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced), and, in this capacity, have engaged, on a continuous basis, one or more persons to work for them as employee(s).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employers, total (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employers refers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced), and, in this capacity, have engaged, on a continuous basis, one or more persons to work for them as employee(s).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Own-account workers, female (% of employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Own-account workers, female (% of employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Own-account workers, male (% of employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Own-account workers, male (% of employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Self-employed, female (% of females employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Self employed workers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners or in cooperative, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" (i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced). Self employed workers include three subcategories: employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Self-employed, male (% of males employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Self employed workers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners or in cooperative, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" (i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced). Self employed workers include three subcategories: employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Self-employed, total (% of total employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Self employed workers are those workers who, working on their own account or with one or a few partners or in cooperative, hold the type of jobs defined as a "self-employment jobs" (i.e. jobs where the remuneration is directly dependent upon the profits derived from the goods and services produced). Self employed workers include three subcategories: employers, own-account workers, and members of producers' cooperatives.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment to population ratio is the proportion of a country's population that is employed. Ages 15 and older are generally considered the working-age population.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time-related underemployment, female (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time-related underemployment, female (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time-related underemployment, male (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time-related underemployment, male (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Time-related underemployment, (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Time-related underemployment, (% of employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Union members (% of total paid employees)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Union members (% of total paid employees)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, (http://laborsta.ilo.org/xls_data_E.html).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Vulnerable employment, total (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Vulnerable employment is unpaid family workers and own-account workers as a percentage of total employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wage and salaried workers, female (% of females employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wage and salary workers, male (% of males employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Wage and salaried workers, total (% of total employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Wage and salaried workers (employees) are those workers who hold the type of jobs defined as "paid employment jobs," where the incumbents hold explicit (written or oral) or implicit employment contracts that give them a basic remuneration that is not directly dependent upon the revenue of the unit for which they work.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, unpaid family workers (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Unpaid family workers are people who work without pay in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Contributing family workers, female (% of females employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold ‘self-employment jobs’ as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Contributing family workers, male (% of males employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Contributing family workers, total (% of total employed)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Contributing family workers are those workers who hold "self-employment jobs" as own-account workers in a market-oriented establishment operated by a related person living in the same household.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per person employed (constant 1990 PPP $)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy. Purchasing power parity (PPP) GDP is GDP converted to 1990 constant international dollars using PPP rates. An international dollar has the same purchasing power over GDP that a U.S. dollar has in the United States.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: GDP per person employed (annual % growth)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: GDP per person employed is gross domestic product (GDP) divided by total employment in the economy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, industry, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, industry, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in industry (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Industry corresponds to divisions 2-5 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories C-F (ISIC revision 3) and includes mining and quarrying (including oil production), manufacturing, construction, and public utilities (electricity, gas, and water).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Informal employment, female (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Informal employment, female (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Informal employment, male (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Informal employment, male (% of total nonagricultural employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in manufacturing (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Manufacturing corresponds to division 3 (ISIC revision 2) or category D (ISIC revision 3). Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ratio of female to male wages in manufacturing (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ratio of female to male wages in manufacturing refers to female to male wages and salaries in manufacturing.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, self-employed (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Self-employed workers are people whose remuneration depends directly on the profits derived from the goods and services they produce, with or without other employees, and include employers, own-account workers, and members of producers cooperatives.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services, female (% of female economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services, male (% of male economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Child employment in services (% of economically active children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employment by economic activity refers to the distribution of economically active children by the major industrial categories (ISIC revision 2 or revision 3). Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade, hotels and restaurants, transport, financial intermediation, real estate, public administration, education, health and social work, other community services, and private household activity. Economically active children refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, services, female (% of female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employees, services, male (% of male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Employment in services (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Employees are people who work for a public or private employer and receive remuneration in wages, salary, commission, tips, piece rates, or pay in kind. Services correspond to divisions 6-9 (ISIC revision 2) or tabulation categories G-P (ISIC revision 3) and include wholesale and retail trade and restaurants and hotels; transport, storage, and communications; financing, insurance, real estate, and business services; and community, social, and personal services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources.Website: http://w3.unece.org/pxweb/DATABASE/STAT/Gender.stat.asp

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Average number of hours spent on unpaid domestic work (housework and child care), male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Economic Commission for Europe (UNECE) Statistical Division Database, compiled from national and international official sources.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, female (% of female children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, male (% of male children ages 7-14)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, study and work, female (% of female children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Study and work refer to children attending school in combination with economic activity.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, study and work, male (% of male children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Study and work refer to children attending school in combination with economic activity.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, study and work (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Work only refers to children involved in economic activity and not attending school.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, work only, female (% of female children in employment, ages 7-14)

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, work only, male (% of male children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Work only refers to children involved in economic activity and not attending school.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, work only (% of children in employment, ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Children in employment, total (% of children ages 7-14)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Children in employment refer to children involved in economic activity for at least one hour in the reference week of the survey. Study and work refer to children attending school in combination with economic activity.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Understanding Children's Work project based on data from ILO, UNICEF and the World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force (15-24 years), female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 to 24 who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force (15-24 years), female (% of total labor force 15-24 years)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-24)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: ILO Key Indicators of the Labour Market (KILM).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force (15-24 years), total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15-24 who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force participation rate for ages 15-24, female (%) (national estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force participation rate for ages 15-24 is the proportion of the population ages 15-24 that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force participation rate for ages 15-24, female (%) (modeled ILO estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 15-24 that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. The participation rates are harmonized to account for differences in national data collection and tabulation methodologies as well as for other country-specific factors such as military service requirements. The series includes both nationally reported and imputed data and only estimates that are national, meaning there are no geographic limitations in coverage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force participation rate is the proportion of the population ages 25-34 that is economically active: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. The participation rates are harmonized to account for differences in national data collection and tabulation methodologies as well as for other country-specific factors such as military service requirements. The series includes both nationally reported and imputed data and only estimates that are national, meaning there are no geographic limitations in coverage.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Part time employment, female (% of total female employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Part time employment, male (% of total male employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Part time employment, female (% of total part time employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Part time employment, total (% of total employment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Part time employment refers to regular employment in which working time is substantially less than normal. Definitions of part time employment differ by country.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with primary education, female (% of female labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with primary education (% of total)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force with primary education is the proportion of the labor force that has a primary education, as a percentage of the total labor force.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with secondary education, male (% of male labor force)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with tertiary education, female (% of female labor force)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force with tertiary education (% of total)

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Labor force, female
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank estimate using ratio from ILO's KILM and World Bank's population.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, female (% of total labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Female labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which women are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, total
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization definition of the economically active population: all people who supply labor for the production of goods and services during a specified period. It includes both the employed and the unemployed. While national practices vary in the treatment of such groups as the armed forces and seasonal or part-time workers, in general the labor force includes the armed forces, the unemployed, and first-time job-seekers, but excludes homemakers and other unpaid caregivers and workers in the informal sector.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, male
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Male labor force comprises all males who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Labor force, male (% of total labor force)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Male labor force as a percentage of the total show the extent to which men are active in the labor force. Labor force comprises people ages 15 and older who meet the International Labour Organization's definition of the economically active population.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, using World Bank population estimates.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, youth female (% of female labor force ages 15-24) (national estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment. Definitions of labor force and unemployment differ by country.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Unemployment, youth female (% of female labor force ages 15-24) (modeled ILO estimate)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Youth unemployment refers to the share of the labor force ages 15-24 without work but available for and seeking employment.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Long-term unemployment, female (% of female unemployment)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Long-term unemployment refers to the number of people with continuous periods of unemployment extending for a year or longer, expressed as a percentage of the total unemployed.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Labour Organization, Key Indicators of the Labour Market database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Long-term unemployment, male (% of male unemployment)
