wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Weighted mean applied tariff is the average of effectively applied rates weighted by the product import shares corresponding to each partner country. Data are classified using the Harmonized System of trade at the six- or eight-digit level. Tariff line data were matched to Standard International Trade Classification (SITC) revision 3 codes to define commodity groups and import weights. To the extent possible, specific rates have been converted to their ad valorem equivalent rates and have been included in the calculation of weighted mean tariffs. Import weights were calculated using the United Nations Statistics Division's Commodity Trade (Comtrade) database. Effectively applied tariff rates at the six- and eight-digit product level are averaged for products in each commodity group. When the effectively applied rate is unavailable, the most favored nation rate is used instead. Primary products are commodities classified in SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 plus division 68 (nonferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using the World Integrated Trade Solution system, based on data from United Nations Conference on Trade and Development's Trade Analysis and Information System (TRAINS) database and the World Trade Organization’s (WTO) Integrated Data Base (IDB) and Consolidated Tariff Schedules (CTS) database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tariff rate, most favored nation, weighted mean, primary products (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Weighted mean most favored nations tariff is the average of most favored nation rates weighted by the product import shares corresponding to each partner country. Data are classified using the Harmonized System of trade at the six- or eight-digit level. Tariff line data were matched to Standard International Trade Classification (SITC) revision 3 codes to define commodity groups and import weights. Import weights were calculated using the United Nations Statistics Division's Commodity Trade (Comtrade) database. Primary products are commodities classified in SITC revision 3 sections 0-4 plus division 68 (nonferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using the World Integrated Trade Solution system, based on data from United Nations Conference on Trade and Development's Trade Analysis and Information System (TRAINS) database and the World Trade Organization’s (WTO) Integrated Data Base (IDB) and Consolidated Tariff Schedules (CTS) database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on textile products from developing countries (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered “developed” regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Agricultural, clothing and textile groups follow the definition in WTO agreements based on the Harmonized System 1992, transposed to current versions by WTO Secretariat. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, World Trade Organization, and International Trade Center. Data are available online at: www.mdg-trade.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Average tariffs imposed by developed countries on textile products from least developed countries (%)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: It is the average tariffs imposed by developed countries on subsets of selected items (agricultural products, textile and clothing exports) that are deemed to be of interest to developing countries. For the purpose of calculating this indicator, Japan in Asia, Canada and the United States in North America, Australia and New Zealand in Oceania and Iceland, Norway, Switzerland and the EU (25 countries included since 2004) in Europe are considered “developed” regions or areas, following the common accepted practice used for MDG indicators. Developing countries are those not listed as developed or transition countries. The list of least developed countries (LDCs) has been agreed by the General Assembly, on the recommendation of the Committee for Development Policy, Economic and Social Council. Agricultural, clothing and textile groups follow the definition in WTO agreements based on the Harmonized System 1992, transposed to current versions by WTO Secretariat. Agricultural products correspond to Harmonized System 1992, chapters 01 to 24 less fish and fish products (chap. 03); in addition to parts of chapters 29, 33, 35, 38, 41, 43, 50 to 53. Textile is mainly covered in chapters 50 to 60. The bulk of clothing products are found in chapters 61-63.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, World Trade Organization, and International Trade Center. Data are available online at: www.mdg-trade.org.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural raw materials imports (% of merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural raw materials comprise SITC section 2 (crude materials except fuels) excluding divisions 22, 27 (crude fertilizers and minerals excluding coal, petroleum, and precious stones), and 28 (metalliferous ores and scrap).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: POL and other energy imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Petroleum and energy products imports in current US dollars. Values are on cif (includes freight and insurance costs).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: POL and other energy imports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Petroleum and energy products imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: "World Bank country economists. "

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in current US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food imports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food imports (% of merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food comprises the commodities in SITC sections 0 (food and live animals), 1 (beverages and tobacco), and 4 (animal and vegetable oils and fats) and SITC division 22 (oil seeds, oil nuts, and oil kernels).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fuel imports (% of merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fuels comprise the commodities in SITC section 3 (mineral fuels).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: ICT goods imports (% total goods imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Information and communication technology goods imports include telecommunications, audio and video, computer and related equipment; electronic components; and other information and communication technology goods. Software is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development's UNCTADstat database at http://unctadstat.unctad.org/ReportFolders/reportFolders.aspx.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Insurance and financial services (% of commercial service imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Insurance and financial services cover freight insurance on goods imported and other direct insurance such as life insurance; financial intermediation services such as commissions, foreign exchange transactions, and brokerage services; and auxiliary services such as financial market operational and regulatory services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Capital goods imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of capital goods in current US dollars. Values are on cif (includes freight and insurance costs).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Capital goods imports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of capital goods, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactures imports (% of merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures comprise the commodities in SITC sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods), excluding division 68 (nonferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ores and metals imports (% of merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ores and metals comprise commodities in SITC sections 27 (crude fertilizer, minerals nes); 28 (metalliferous ores, scrap); and 68 (non-ferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from economies in the Arab World (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from economies in the Arab World are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from economies in the Arab World. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports, WB (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total merchandise imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in current US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports show the c.i.f. value of goods received from the rest of the world valued in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Trade Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from high-income economies (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from high-income economies are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from high-income economies according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total merchandise imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies outside region (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies outside region are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from other developing economies in other World Bank regions according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in East Asia & Pacific (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in East Asia and Pacific are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the East Asia and Pacific region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Europe & Central Asia (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Europe and Central Asia are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the Europe and Central Asia region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Latin America & the Caribbean (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Latin America and the Caribbean are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the Latin America and the Caribbean region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Middle East & North Africa (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Middle East and North Africa are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the Middle East and North Africa region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in South Asia (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in South Asia are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the South Asia region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Sub-Saharan Africa (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies in Sub-Saharan Africa are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from developing economies in the Sub-Saharan Africa region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports by the reporting economy, residual (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports by the reporting economy residuals are the total merchandise imports by the reporting economy from the rest of the world as reported in the IMF's Direction of trade database, less the sum of imports by the reporting economy from high-, low-, and middle-income economies according to the World Bank classification of economies. Includes trade with unspecified partners or with economies not covered by World Bank classification. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports by the reporting economy (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports by the reporting economy are the total merchandise imports by the reporting economy from the rest of the world, as reported in the IMF's Direction of trade database. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise imports from developing economies within region (% of total merchandise imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise imports from developing economies within region are the sum of merchandise imports by the reporting economy from other developing economies in the same World Bank region according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise imports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data. No figures are shown for high-income economies, because they are a separate category in the World Bank classification of economies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Import value index (2000 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Import value indexes are the current value of imports (c.i.f.) converted to U.S. dollars and expressed as a percentage of the average for the base period (2000). UNCTAD's import value indexes are reported for most economies. For selected economies for which UNCTAD does not publish data, the import value indexes are derived from import volume indexes (line 73) and corresponding unit value indexes of imports (line 75) in the IMF's International Financial Statistics.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Handbook of Statistics and data files, and International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other consumer goods imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumer goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in current dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other consumer goods imports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Consumer goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Computer, communications and other services (% of commercial service imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Computer, communications and other services (% of commercial service imports) include such activities as international telecommunications, and postal and courier services; computer data; news-related service transactions between residents and nonresidents; construction services; royalties and license fees; miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services; and personal, cultural, and recreational services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, manufactures (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of manufactures (SITC 5 through 9 excluding 68) in current US dollars. Values are on c.i.f. basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, manufactures (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Imports of manufactures (SITC 5 through 9 excluding 68) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, primary (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in current US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, primary (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Primary goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, total (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Intermediate goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) current US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Intermediate goods imports, total (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Intermediate goods imports, cif (includes freight and insurance costs) in 1987 constant US dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Commercial service imports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Commercial service imports are total service imports minus imports of government services not included elsewhere. International transactions in services are defined by the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual (1993) as the economic output of intangible commodities that may be produced, transferred, and consumed at the same time. Definitions may vary among reporting economies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transport services (% of commercial service imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transport services (% of commercial service imports) covers all transport services (sea, air, land, internal waterway, space, and pipeline) performed by residents of one economy for those of another and involving the carriage of passengers, movement of goods (freight), rental of carriers with crew, and related support and auxiliary services. Excluded are freight insurance, which is included in insurance services; goods procured in ports by nonresident carriers and repairs of transport equipment, which are included in goods; repairs of railway facilities, harbors, and airfield facilities, which are included in construction services; and rental of carriers without crew, which is included in other services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Travel services (% of commercial service imports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Travel services (% of commercial service imports) covers goods and services acquired from an economy by travelers in that economy for their own use during visits of less than one year for business or personal purposes. Travel services include the goods and services consumed by travelers, such as lodging, meals, and transport (within the economy visited).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Tobacco, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Tobacco (any origin), unmanufactured, general import , cif, US
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: US Department of Agriculture, World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Terms of Trade
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The terms of trade effect equals capacity to import less exports of goods and services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Total Reserves
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total reserves comprise holdings of monetary gold, special drawing rights, reserves of IMF members held by the IMF, and holdings of foreign exchange under the control of monetary authorities.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff calculations based on Datastream data.

wb:indicator.wb:name: TSP, $/mt, current$
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: TSP (triple superphosphate), up to September 2006 bulk, spot, f.o.b. US Gulf; from October 2006 onwards Tunisian, granular, f.o.b.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: Fertilizer Week; Fertilizer International; World Bank.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise Terms of Trade (1987 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net barter (merchandise) terms of trade (1987 = 100) are the ratio of the export price index to the corresponding import price index measured relative to the base year of 1987.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Net barter terms of trade index (2000 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Net barter terms of trade index is calculated as the percentage ratio of the export unit value indexes to the import unit value indexes, measured relative to the base year 2000. Unit value indexes are based on data reported by countries that demonstrate consistency under UNCTAD quality controls, supplemented by UNCTAD’s estimates using the previous year’s trade values at the Standard International Trade Classification three-digit level as weights. To improve data coverage, especially for the latest periods, UNCTAD constructs a set of average prices indexes at the three-digit product classification of the Standard International Trade Classification revision 3 using UNCTAD’s Commodity Price Statistics, interna­tional and national sources, and UNCTAD secretariat estimates and calculates unit value indexes at the country level using the current year’s trade values as weights.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Handbook of Statistics and data files, and International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Number of product (exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Number of products (at SITC, Revision 3, 3-digit group level) exported by country or country grouping; this figure includes only those products that are greater than 100,000 dollars or more than 0.3 per cent of the country’s or country group’s total exports. The maximum number of products is 261.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNCTAD Statistical Office, also reported in the UNCTAD Handbook of Statistics, various issues (http://unctadstat.unctad.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export product concentration index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This indicator reflects the Herfindahl-Hirschmann index measure of the degree of export concentration within a country. The sectoral Hirschmann index is defined as the square root of the sum of the squared shares of exports of each industry in total exports for the region under study. Takes a value between 0 and 1, with 1 indicating that only a single product is exported. Higher values indicate that exports are concentrated in fewer sectors. On the contrary, values closer to 0 reflect a more equal distribution of market shares among exporters. Note that this type of concentration indicator tends to be quite vulnerable to cyclical fluctuations in relative-prices, in a way that commodity price rises make commodity exporters look more concentrated.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNCTAD Statistical Office, also reported in the UNCTAD Handbook of Statistics, various issues (http://unctadstat.unctad.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export product diversification index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: The diversification index signals whether the structure of exports by product of a given country or group of countries differ from the structure of product of the world. Diversification index is computed by measuring absolute deviation of the country share from world structure. Diversification index that ranges from 0 to 1 reveals the extent of the differences between the structure of trade of the country or country group and the world average. The index value closer to 1 indicates a bigger difference from the world average. It is constructed as the inverse of a Herfindahl index, using disaggregated exports at 4 digits (following the STIC3).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNCTAD Statistical Office, also reported in the UNCTAD Handbook of Statistics, various issues (http://unctadstat.unctad.org/).

wb:indicator.wb:name: Market export diversification index (0=less concentrated; 1=more concentrated)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Market export diversification (Herfindahl) index is a flow-weighted concentration index normalized to a range between 0 and 1--one being more concentrated. The share in total export of 220 potential partners for each destination is used. Due to lack of some country's export data, "mirror data" is used (partner's import from that country).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using UN Comtrade data through the WITS platform.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Product export diversification index (0=less concentrated; 1=more concentrated)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Product export diversification (Herfindahl) index is a flow-weighted concentration index normalized to a range between 0 and 1--one being more concentrated. The Harmonized Commodity Description and Coding System (HS) 6 digit product classification is used. Due to lack of some country's export data, "mirror data" is used (partner's import from that country).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates using UN Comtrade data through the WITS platform.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise export price index (1987 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This item is a price index measuring changes in the aggregate price level of a country's merchandise exports f.o.b. over time.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export price index, (nonfactor) services
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: This item is a price index measuring changes in the aggregate price level of a country's non-factor services exports over time with 1987 price index=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 1 (volume index)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of commodity 1 with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 2 (volume index)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of commodity 2 with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 3 (volume index)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of commodity 3 with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 4 (volume index)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of commodity 4 with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export volume index, manufactures
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of manufactures with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise export volume index
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports volume index with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export volume index (2000 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume indexes are derived from UNCTAD's volume index series and are the ratio of the export value indexes to the corresponding unit value indexes. Unit value indexes are based on data reported by countries that demonstrate consistency under UNCTAD quality controls, supplemented by UNCTAD’s estimates using the previous year’s trade values at the Standard International Trade Classification three-digit level as weights. To improve data coverage, especially for the latest periods, UNCTAD constructs a set of average prices indexes at the three-digit product classification of the Standard International Trade Classification revision 3 using UNCTAD’s Commodity Price Statistics, interna­tional and national sources, and UNCTAD secretariat estimates and calculates unit value indexes at the country level using the current year’s trade values as weights. For economies for which UNCTAD does not publish data, the export volume indexes (lines 72) in the IMF's International Financial Statistics are used.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Handbook of Statistics and data files, and International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export volume index, (nonfactor) services
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of (non-factor) services. Data; Volume index with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export volume index, other primary commodities
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export volume index of other primary commodities with 1987=100.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Agricultural raw materials exports (% of merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Agricultural raw materials comprise SITC section 2 (crude materials except fuels) excluding divisions 22, 27 (crude fertilizers and minerals excluding coal, petroleum, and precious stones), and 28 (metalliferous ores and scrap).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 1 (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 1 in current US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 1 (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 1 in 1987 constant US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 2 (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 2 in current US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 2 (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 2 in 1987 constant US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 3 (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 3 in current US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 3 (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 3 in 1987 constant US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 4 (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 4 in current US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Exports of commodity 4 (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of commodity 4 in 1987 constant US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Food exports (% of merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Food comprises the commodities in SITC sections 0 (food and live animals), 1 (beverages and tobacco), and 4 (animal and vegetable oils and fats) and SITC division 22 (oil seeds, oil nuts, and oil kernels).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Fuel exports (% of merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Fuels comprise SITC section 3 (mineral fuels).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: ICT goods exports (% of total goods exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Information and communication technology goods exports include telecommunications, audio and video, computer and related equipment; electronic components; and other information and communication technology goods. Software is excluded.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development's UNCTADstat database at http://unctadstat.unctad.org/ReportFolders/reportFolders.aspx.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Insurance and financial services (% of commercial service exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Insurance and financial services cover freight insurance on goods exported and other direct insurance such as life insurance; financial intermediation services such as commissions, foreign exchange transactions, and brokerage services; and auxiliary services such as financial market operational and regulatory services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactures exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures comprise the commodities in SITC sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods), excluding division 68 (nonferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the COMTRADE database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactures exports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures comprise the commodities in SITC sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods), excluding division 68 (nonferrous metals) in 1987 constant US dollars. Values are on fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Manufactures exports (% of merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Manufactures comprise commodities in SITC sections 5 (chemicals), 6 (basic manufactures), 7 (machinery and transport equipment), and 8 (miscellaneous manufactured goods), excluding division 68 (non-ferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Ores and metals exports (% of merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Ores and metals comprise the commodities in SITC sections 27 (crude fertilizer, minerals nes); 28 (metalliferous ores, scrap); and 68 (non-ferrous metals).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates from the Comtrade database maintained by the United Nations Statistics Division.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to economies in the Arab World (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to economies in the Arab World are the sum of merchandise exports by the reporting economy to economies in the Arab World. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports, WB (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports (current US$) show the f.o.b. value of goods provided to the rest of the world valued in U.S. dollars. They are classified using the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC). Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports show the f.o.b. value of goods provided to the rest of the world valued in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Trade Organization.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to high-income economies (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to high-income economies are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to high-income economies according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports (constant 1987 US$) show the f.o.b. value of goods provided to the rest of the world valued in U.S. dollars. They are classified using the Standard International Trade Classification (SITC). Data are in constant U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies outside region (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies outside region are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to other developing economies in other World Bank regions according to the World Bank classification of economies. Data are expressed as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in East Asia & Pacific (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in East Asia and Pacific are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the East Asia and Pacific region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Europe & Central Asia (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Europe and Central Asia are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the Europe and Central Asia region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Latin America & the Caribbean (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Latin America and the Caribbean are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the Latin America and the Caribbean region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Middle East & North Africa (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Middle East and North Africa are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the Middle East and North Africa region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in South Asia (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in South Asia are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the South Asia region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Sub-Saharan Africa (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies in Sub-Saharan Africa are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to developing economies in the Sub-Saharan Africa region according to World Bank classification of economies. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports by the reporting economy, residual (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports by the reporting economy residuals are the total merchandise exports by the reporting economy to the rest of the world as reported in the IMF's Direction of trade database, less the sum of exports by the reporting economy to high-, low-, and middle-income economies according to the World Bank classification of economies. Includes trade with unspecified partners or with economies not covered by World Bank classification. Data are as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports by the reporting economy (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports by the reporting economy are the total merchandise exports by the reporting economy to the rest of the world, as reported in the IMF's Direction of trade database. Data are in current US$.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Merchandise exports to developing economies within region (% of total merchandise exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Merchandise exports to developing economies within region are the sum of merchandise exports from the reporting economy to other developing economies in the same World Bank region as a percentage of total merchandise exports by the economy. Data are computed only if at least half of the economies in the partner country group had non-missing data. No figures are shown for high-income economies, because they are a separate category in the World Bank classification of economies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank staff estimates based data from International Monetary Fund's Direction of Trade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Export value index (2000 = 100)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Export values are the current value of exports (f.o.b.) converted to U.S. dollars and expressed as a percentage of the average for the base period (2000). UNCTAD's export value indexes are reported for most economies. For selected economies for which UNCTAD does not publish data, the export value indexes are derived from export volume indexes (line 72) and corresponding unit value indexes of exports (line 74) in the IMF's International Financial Statistics.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, Handbook of Statistics and data files, and International Monetary Fund, International Financial Statistics.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other primary commodities exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of other primary commodities in current US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Other primary commodities exports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Exports of other primary commodities in 1987 constant US dollars and fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Computer, communications and other services (% of commercial service exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Computer, communications and other services (% of commercial service exports) include such activities as international telecommunications, and postal and courier services; computer data; news-related service transactions between residents and nonresidents; construction services; royalties and license fees; miscellaneous business, professional, and technical services; and personal, cultural, and recreational services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Commercial service exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Commercial service exports are total service exports minus exports of government services not included elsewhere. International transactions in services are defined by the IMF's Balance of Payments Manual (1993) as the economic output of intangible commodities that may be produced, transferred, and consumed at the same time. Definitions may vary among reporting economies.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary commodities exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Primary Commodities exports in current US dollars. Values are in fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Primary commodities exports (constant US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Total Primary Commodities exports in 1987 constant US dollars. Values are in fob basis.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: World Bank country economists.

wb:indicator.wb:name: High-technology exports (current US$)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: High-technology exports are products with high R&D intensity, such as in aerospace, computers, pharmaceuticals, scientific instruments, and electrical machinery. Data are in current U.S. dollars.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, Comtrade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: High-technology exports (% of manufactured exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: High-technology exports are products with high R&D intensity, such as in aerospace, computers, pharmaceuticals, scientific instruments, and electrical machinery.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: United Nations, Comtrade database.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Transport services (% of commercial service exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Transport services (% of commercial service exports) covers all transport services (sea, air, land, internal waterway, space, and pipeline) performed by residents of one economy for those of another and involving the carriage of passengers, movement of goods (freight), rental of carriers with crew, and related support and auxiliary services. Excluded are freight insurance, which is included in insurance services; goods procured in ports by nonresident carriers and repairs of transport equipment, which are included in goods; repairs of railway facilities, harbors, and airfield facilities, which are included in construction services; and rental of carriers without crew, which is included in other services.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Travel services (% of commercial service exports)
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Travel services (% of commercial service exports) covers goods and services acquired from an economy by travelers in that economy for their own use during visits of less than one year for business or personal purposes. Travel services include the goods and services consumed by travelers, such as lodging and meals and transport (within the economy visited).
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: International Monetary Fund, Balance of Payments Statistics Yearbook and data files.

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of newly recruited public primary school teachers who are female. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of newly recruited public lower secondary school teachers who are female. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with mixed-sex toilets. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools without separate girls and boys toilets. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with electricity. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools with access to permanent sources of electrical power (i.e. grid/mains connection, wind, water, solar, permanently fuel-powered generator, etc.). Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools without electricity. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools with no access to permanent sources of electrical power (i.e. grid/mains connection, wind, water, solar, permanently fuel-powered generator, etc.). Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools without potable water. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools without a drinking water facility or water delivery point that is designed to protect water from external contamination, particularly of fecal origin. Examples of potable drinking water facilities include pipe-borne water, protected well, borehole, protected spring water and rainwater. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools without toilets. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools without a pit latrine, flush toilet, pour-flush toilet or a composting toilet. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with potable water. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools without a drinking water facility or water delivery point that is designed to protect water from external contamination, particularly of fecal origin. Examples of potable drinking water facilities include pipe-borne water, protected well, borehole, protected spring water and rainwater. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with single-sex toilets. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools with separate girls and boys toilets or single-sex educational institutions with toilets. Schools are counted as having toilets if they have a pit latrine, an improved pit latrine, a flush toilet, a pour-flush toilet or a composting toilet. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Percentage of schools with toilets. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of primary schools with a pit latrine, an improved pit latrine, a flush toilet, a pour-flush toilet or a composting toilet. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics

wb:indicator.wb:name: Africa Dataset: Schools census return rate. Primary. Public
wb:indicator.wb:sourceNote: Share of all primary school questionnaires that were returned with at least some usable data and captured in the EMIS system. Data available for African countries only. For more information, consult to the UNESCO Institute for Statistics' Regional Data Collections page.
wb:indicator.wb:sourceOrganization: UNESCO Institute for Statistics
